dep.name: schematron
dep.title: ISO SCHEMATRON 2010
dep.desc:
ISO Schematron is a language for making assertion about the presence or absense of patterns in XML documents. It is typically used for as a schema language, or to augment existing schema languages, and to check business rules. It is very powerful, yet quite simple: a developer only need know XPath and about five other elements.
This is an open source implementation of ISO Schematron in XSLT. Although ISO does not allow reference implementations which might compete with the text of the standard, this code has been compiled by Rick Jelliffe, inventor of Schematron and editor of the ISO standard; so developers can certainly use it as an unofficial reference implementation for clarification.
This implementation is based on one by Oliver Becker. API documentation is available separately; try www.schematron.com for this. Funding for this stylesheet over the years has come from Topologi Pty. Ltd., Geotempo Ltd., and ASCC, Tapei.
There are two versions of this skeleton: one is tailored for XSLT1 processors and the other is tailored for XSLT2 processors. Future versions of the XSLT2 skeleton may support more features than that the XSLT 1 skeleton.
dep.author: Rick Jelliffe
dep.xslt: iso_schematron_skeleton.xsl To summarize, a basic 2 step process flow for some commandline processor is like this: I) XSLT -input=xxx.sch -output=xxx.xsl -stylesheet=iso_schematron_skeleton.xsl II) XSLT -input=document.xml -output=xxx-document.results -stylesheet=xxx.xsl

dep.name: xslt.1.functx
dep.title: FunctX library
dep.desc: The FunctX function library is a set of useful functions on XML documents and data. It comes in two flavors: XQuery 1.0 and XSLT 2.0. Where possible, XPath 2.0 is is used in order to keep the function definitions as consistent as possible across the two languages. The source code for the functions is available under the GNU-LGPL license. However, the longer descriptions of the functions and the design of the FunctX Web sites is copyrighted and may only be used with permission.This site also includes descriptions and examples of the XQuery and XPath built-in functions, taken with permission from the book XQuery (2007, O'Reilly Media).We hope you find these functions useful and that you will take the time to provide feedback and/or contribute your own functions.
dep.author: Priscilla Walmsley

dep.name: xray
dep.title: xray
dep.desc: xray is a framework for writing XQuery unit tests on MarkLogic Server.
dep.author: Rob Whitby

dep.name: roxy
dep.title: Roxy
dep.desc: Roxy (RObust XQuerY Framework) is a lightweight framework for quickly developing well-structured, easily maintained XQuery applications. Roxy was heavily inspired by Ruby On Rails and CakePHP.
dep.author: Paxton Hare
Dan Cassel

dep.name: xqueryparser.xq
dep.title: xqueryparser.xq
dep.desc: An parser for XQuery 3.0 and MarkLogic extensions.
dep.author: John Snelson

dep.name: transform.xq
dep.title: transform.xq
dep.desc: An extensible transformation library for XQuery 3.0.
dep.author: John Snelson

dep.name: rbtree.xq
dep.title: rbtree.xq
dep.desc: An implementation of a red/black tree built using XQuery 3.0 higher order functions, and an associative map library built on top of it..
dep.author: John Snelson

dep.name: functional.xq
dep.title: functional.xq
dep.desc: A library of useful functionality for working with XQuery 3.0 higher order functions. Includes a number of functions from the standard Haskell prelude, as well as functions to perform currying, function composition, and Y-combination.
dep.author: John Snelson

dep.name: data.xq
dep.title: xqueryparser.xq
dep.desc: An XQuery 3.0 library for defining algebraic data types, and performing structural pattern matching on them..
dep.author: John Snelson

dep.name: xquery.1.functx
dep.title: FunctX library
dep.desc: The FunctX function library is a set of useful functions on XML documents and data. It comes in two flavors: XQuery 1.0 and XSLT 2.0. Where possible, XPath 2.0 is is used in order to keep the function definitions as consistent as possible across the two languages. The source code for the functions is available under the GNU-LGPL license. However, the longer descriptions of the functions and the design of the FunctX Web sites is copyrighted and may only be used with permission.This site also includes descriptions and examples of the XQuery and XPath built-in functions, taken with permission from the book XQuery (2007, O'Reilly Media).We hope you find these functions useful and that you will take the time to provide feedback and/or contribute your own functions.
dep.author: Priscilla Walmsley

dep.name: ml-xproc-library
dep.title: ML XProc Libraries
dep.desc: XProc libraries for working with MarkLogic.
dep.author: Philip Fennell

desc.xhtml:p: This project provides RELAX NG grammars for XSLT stylesheets. Because stylesheets are required to have a version number, it's straightforward for a RELAX NG validator to choose between the xslt10.rnc and xslt20.rnc grammars.
As work on XSLT 3.0 stabilizes, I plan to include support for that as well.
Having a RELAX NG grammar makes syntax directed editing of XSLT stylesheets much easier in tools like Emacs and oXygen that support RELAX NG.

dep.name: xqib
dep.title: xqib - xquery in the browser
dep.desc: XQIB allows you to program client-side Web applications with XQuery instead of JavaScript. It works in most modern browsers (IE9, Firefox 3.6+, Chrome 8, Safari 5) and does not require the installation of any plugin. XQuery is a W3C standard, just like HTML and XML, and is perfectly tailored for working with HTML, XML and REST. This means more elegant programs and less code. Moreover, by using an XQuery Web application server (such as MarkLogic or Sausalito) in conjunction with XQIB, having the same language on both the server and the client side allows you to reuse your code.
dep.author: FLWOR Foundation, ETH Zurich Systems Group and Oracle

dep.name: saxon-ce
dep.title: Saxon-CE
dep.desc: Saxon-CE (client edition) is Saxonica's implementation of XSLT 2.0 for use on web browsers. The current release is Saxon-CE 1.1. Unlike previous releases, Saxon-CE 1.1 is open-source software.
dep.author: Saxonica

dep.name: qunit
dep.title: QUnit - A JavaScript Unit Testing Framework
dep.author: John Resig
Joern Zaefferer

dep.name: prettify
dep.title: Prettify.js library
dep.desc: A Javascript module and CSS file that allows syntax highlighting of source code snippets in an html page.
dep.author: Mike Samuel
